{{Infobox referendum |name = Measure 97 |title =Increases corporate minimum tax when sales exceed $25 million; funds education, healthcare, senior services |yes = 808,310 |no = 1,164,658 |invalid = |total = 1,972,968 |map = Oregon 2014 Measure 86.svg |mapdivision=county |notes=Source: Oregon Secretary of State<ref name=results>{{cite web|url=https://sos.oregon.gov/elections/Documents/results/november-2016-results.pdf|title=Results: 2016 General Election, November 8, 2016|publisher=Oregon Secretary of State|accessdate=December 12, 2016}}</ref> }} '''Oregon Ballot Measure 97''' was a [[ballot measure]] in the [[Oregon state elections, 2016|2016 election]] in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Oregon]]. The initiative asked voters to determine whether or not to impose a 2.5 percent [[gross receipts tax]] on [[C corporation]]s with Oregon sales exceeding $25 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sos.oregon.gov/elections/Documents/ESFI/97-final-es-08112016.pdf|format=PDF|title=Measure 97: Explanatory Statement|publisher=[[Oregon Secretary of State]]|accessdate=November 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/08/faq_oregons_corporate_tax_meas.html |title=FAQ: Oregon's corporate tax measure is a big deal. Here's why.|work=[[The Oregonian]]|date=August 17, 2016|first=Hillary|last=Borrud|accessdate=November 1, 2016}}</ref> [[S corporation]]s and [[Benefit corporation|benefit companies]] (companies that benefit society and the environment, as determined under state law) would be exempt from the tax.<ref>"Measure 97 Description and Analysis", p. 3</ref><ref> Katy Sword, [http://www.oregonbusiness.com/article/item/17296-three-b-corps-on-measure-97#itemCommentsAnchor Strange bedfellows: Measure 97 and the benefit company exemption], ''Oregon Business'' (November 1, 2016).</ref> It was estimated the measure would raise $3 billion annually for the state, if passed.<ref name="opb most">{{cite news|title=What's The Most Expensive Political Battle In Oregon? Measure 97|url=http://www.opb.org/news/series/election-2016/oregon-measure-97-tax-increase-campaign-spending/|accessdate=November 1, 2016|publisher=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting]]|date=October 23, 2016|first=Andrew|last=Selsky}}</ref>
The nonpartisan Oregon Legislative Revenue Office determined that of the some 250,000 businesses registered in Oregon, 951 would be subject to the tax; of these, the hundred largest taxpayers would pay about two-thirds of the monies raised. The same report estimated that wholesale companies in Oregon would see their taxes grow by almost $600 million, a 583 percent increase. Taxes on Oregon retailers would increase by $535 million, a 766 percent jump. Health care firms operating in Oregon would experience a 1,211 percent increase in their taxes, adding almost $100 million per year to the cost of health care across the state.<ref name="RogowayFAQ">{{cite news|last=Rogoway|first=Mike|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2016/10/measure_97_faq_how_the_tax_wou.html |title=Measure 97 FAQ: How the tax would work, who would pay, where the money goes|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]/OregonLive|date=October 28, 2016<!--(updated November 1, 2016)-->|access-date=November 7, 2016}}</ref>
During the state's general election held in November 2016, Oregon voters defeated the measure 59 percent (opposed) to 41 percent.<ref name=results/>
==Support and opposition== [[File:Oregon Ballot Measure 97, 2016, voters' pamphlet.jpg|thumb|right|Listing in the 2016 voters' pamphlet]]
The campaigns for and against the ballot measure raised the most money ever over a ballot measure in Oregon.<ref name="PBJ costliest">{{cite news|last1=Kish|first1=Matthew|title=Measure 97 now costliest in Oregon history|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/news/2016/10/24/measure-97-now-costliest-in-oregon-history.html|accessdate=November 1, 2016|work=Portland Business Journal|date=October 24, 2016|publisher=[[American City Business Journals]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Achen|first1=Paris|title=Measure 97 breaks fundraising record|url=http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/328545-208392-measure-97-breaks-fundraising-record|accessdate=November 1, 2016|work=[[Portland Tribune]]|date=October 21, 2016|publisher=[[Pamplin Media Group]]|oclc=46708462}}</ref> By the week before Election Day, combined fundraising for the two campaigns had reached $40 million.<ref name="Mapes">{{cite news|last=Mapes|first=Jeff|url=http://www.opb.org/news/series/election-2016/measure-97-money-raised/ |title=Measure 97 Campaign Hits $40 Million Mark After Last-Minute Contributions|publisher=[[Oregon Public Broadcasting]]|date=November 2, 2016|access-date=November 7, 2016}}</ref> Opponents of the measure outspent proponents of the measure; the anti-Measure 97 campaign, the '''Defeat the Tax on Oregon Sales Committee''', raised almost $26 million, while the pro-Measure 97 committee '''Yes on 97''' raised $14 million.<ref name="Mapes"/> A separate pro-Measure 97 group, Defend Oregon, also raised funds in support of the measure's passage.<ref name="Mapes"/><ref name="Borrud-Oct5">{{cite news|first=Hillary|last=Borrud|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2016/10/opponents_of_corporate_tax_mea_1.html |title=Opponents of corporate tax measure report raising $16.8 million|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=October 5, 2016|access-date=November 7, 2016}}</ref>
The major supporters of the Measure 97 were [[labor union]]s, and in particular the [[Oregon Education Association]], the state's primary teachers' union,<ref name="Johnson">{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Kirk|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/09/us/measure-97-seeking-to-raise-corporate-taxes-splits-oregon-voters.html |title=Measure 97, Seeking to Raise Corporate Taxes, Splits Oregon Voters|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 8, 2016|access-date=November 1, 2016}}</ref> which contributed a total of $2.1 million to the campaign in support of Measure 97.<ref name="Mapes"/> The [[Service Employees International Union]] (SEIU) Local 503, which is "the largest union representing Oregon state government workers", gave almost $3 million to the pro-Measure 97 campaign.<ref name="Mapes"/> The [[American Federation of Teachers]] and the Oregon [[American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees]] also contributed to the pro-Measure 97 campaign.<ref name="Borrud-Oct5"/>
Major corporations mostly opposed the law.<ref name="Johnson"/> Companies and [[trade associations]] that contributed to the campaign against the measure include, among others, [[Amazon.com]], [[General Motors]], [[Kroger]]/[[Fred Meyer]],<ref name="Johnson"/> [[J.P. Morgan Chase]], [[Wal-Mart]],<ref name="Mapes"/> [[Costco]], [[Safeway Inc.|Safeway]]/[[Albertsons]],<ref name="RogowayFAQ"/> the Oregon Association of Realtors, [[Jive Software]], [[Comcast]], [[Pacific Seafood]], and the [[Craft Brew Alliance]].<ref name="Borrud-Oct5"/>
[[Governor of Oregon|Governor]] [[Kate Brown]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], supported the measure, while Brown's opponent in the [[Oregon gubernatorial special election, 2016|2016 gubernatorial election]], [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee [[William C. Pierce|William C. "Bud" Pierce]], opposed the measure.<ref name="Johnson"/>
==Polling== A poll conducted by DHM Research during September 1–6 showed 60 percent of respondents were in favor of Measure 97, with 30 percent opposed. Another poll conducted by icitizen during September 2–7 found that 59 percent of 610 respondents were in favor of the measure passing, with 21 percent opposed. However, support decreased to 40 percent and opposition increased to 31 percent after participants heard arguments against Measure 97. The poll's margin of error was 4 percent.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/322387-201919-poll-support-for-measure-97-erodes-when-voters-hear-pros-cons|title=Poll: Support for Measure 97 erodes when voters hear pros/cons|first=Paris|last=Achen|date=September 13, 2016|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=Portland Tribune}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Corporate tax in the United States]] * [[List of Oregon ballot measures]]

{{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {{use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Anat Kamm 9.jpg|thumb|Anat Kamm]] The '''Anat Kamm–Uri Blau affair''' refers to a leak of thousands of classified [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF) documents by the former Israeli soldier Anat Kamm. During her military service as an assistant in the [[Central Command (Israel)|Central Command]] bureau, Kamm secretly copied thousands of classified documents, including many confidential documents. After she finished her military service, Kamm copied the documents to a CD and leaked it to the Israeli ''[[Haaretz]]'' journalist [[Uri Blau]]. On these acts, Kamm was later on convicted of espionage and providing confidential information without authorization. Information from the leak suggested that the military had defied a ruling by the [[Supreme Court of Israel]] against assassinating wanted militants in the [[West Bank]] who could potentially be arrested safely.{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2010/04/01/israeli-woman-detained-military-leak-accusation/ |title=Israeli woman detained on military leak accusation |date=1 April 2010 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=[[Fox News]] |accessdate=9 July 2013}}{{cite news|last=Kampeas |first=Ron |authorlink=Ron Kampeas |url=http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/03/29/1011331/israel-gags-news-of-journalist-under-house-arrest |title=Israel gags news of soldier turned journalist under arrest |publisher=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] |date=29 March 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402204513/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/03/29/1011331/israel-gags-news-of-journalist-under-house-arrest |archivedate=2 April 2010 }}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/israeli-leak-suspect-held-in-secret-house-arrest-1930672.html |title=Israeli leak suspect held in secret house arrest |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=30 March 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010 |location=London |first=Donald |last=MacIntyre |authorlink=Donald Macintyre (journalist)}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/journalist-on-the-run-from-israel-is-hiding-in-britain-1934015.html |title=Journalist on the run from Israel is hiding in Britain |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=2 April 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010 |location=London |first=Kim |last=Sengupta}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/02/israeli-journalist-anat-kam-house-arrest |title=Israeli journalist Anat Kamm under secret house arrest since December |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=2 April 2010|accessdate=26 October 2010 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101013172755/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/apr/02/israeli-journalist-anat-kam-house-arrest| archivedate= 13 October 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article7086417.ece |title=Israel arrests soldier Anat Kamm over targeted-killings 'leak' |newspaper=[[The Times]] |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}}{{subscription required}} Facts in the case were subjected to an Israeli [[gag order]]. Given that Kamm worked as a gossip journalist dealing with media affairs, the case became well known to journalists, who started reporting on it using indirect descriptions.{{cite news |author=Yitzchak Tessler |date=24 January 2010 |script-title=he:איך עיתונאית עצורה חודש וכולם שותקים? |language=he |trans-title=How come a journalist is detained a month and everyone is silent? |url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART2/043/956.html |publisher=[[nrg Maariv|nrg]] |accessdate=10 September 2014}} The gag order was ultimately circumvented and broken from abroad, notably through U.S.-based blogsite [[Tikun Olam (blog)|Tikun Olam]]. According to the indictment, Kamm illegally copied over 2,000 classified documents during her military service at the IDF.{{cite news |author=Yuval Goren |author2=Avi Ashkenazi |date=8 April 2012 |url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/1/ART2/090/636.html#after_maavaron |script-title=he:העיתונאית ענת קם מואשמת בריגול חמור |language=Hebrew |trans-title=Journalist Anat Kam Accused of Espionage |publisher=[[nrg Maariv]] |accessdate=2014-02-05}}{{cite news |author=Vered Luvitch |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3871970,00.html |script-title=he:חיילת-מרגלת: גנבה אלפי מסמכים 'סופר-מסווגים' |language=Hebrew |trans-title=Soldier-spy: stealing thousands of "super-classified" documents |publisher=[[Ynet]] |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}{{cite news |author=Gilad Grossman |date=8 April 2010 |url=http://news.walla.co.il/?w=//1660912 |script-title=he:עיתונאית מואשמת בהדלפת מסמכים סודיים |language=Hebrew |trans-title=Journalist accused of leaking secret documents |publisher=[[Walla!]] |accessdate=2014-02-05}}{{cite news|script-title=he:העיתונאית ענת קם נעצרה בחשד לריגול |language=he |trans-title=Journalist Anat Kam was arrested on suspicion of espionage |url=http://reshet.ynet.co.il/חדשות/News/Politics/Security/Article,41194.aspx |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100411050858/http://reshet.ynet.co.il/%D7%97%D7%93%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%AA/News/Politics/Security/Article%2C41194.aspx |archivedate=11 April 2010 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite news |first=Abe |last=Selig |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Indictment-says-Kamm-sought-to-harm-state-security |title=Indictment says Kamm sought to harm state security |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010}} Israeli law enforcement sources said the documents include "operational military information, security and situation assessments, meetings' minutes and protocols, highly sensitive intelligence information, orders of deployment and battle, drill briefings, and warfare doctrines for the West Bank".{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3871981,00.html |title=Journalist accused of leaking secret IDF documents |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=28 November 2008 |accessdate=26 October 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028060500/http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0%2C7340%2CL-3871981%2C00.html |archivedate=28 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} [[Shin Bet]] chief [[Yuval Diskin]] said that the case "had the potential to cause grave damage to state security", and defined the documents as "the kind that any intelligence agency would be delighted to get its hands on". == People involved in the affair == ===Anat Kamm=== [[File:Anat Kam 2.jpg|thumb|100px|left|Anat Kamm at the Eilat Journalism Conference, December 2008]] Anat Kamm or Anat Kam ({{lang-he|ענת קם}}, born 1987) is an [[Israel]]i [[journalist]]. Kamm was born in 1987 in [[Jerusalem]]. She studied at the [[Hebrew University Secondary School]]. In her youth, she wrote for the local newspaper ''Jerusalem'' (now ''Yediot Jerusalem'') and for the youth channel of the Israeli website [[Walla!]]. In 2005, Kamm began her [[Israel Defense Forces#Regular service|military service]] in the Israeli Defence Forces. In July 2005, she was assigned to work as a clerk in the office of the commander of the [[Israeli Central Command]]. In January 2006, she began her training at an officer's course, but was eventually eliminated and afterwards was assigned to work as an assistant in the office of the commander of Israeli Central Command, [[Israel Defense Forces ranks|Major General]] [[Yair Naveh]]. After she finished her military service, she studied for a bachelor's degree in [[History]] and [[Philosophy]] at [[Tel Aviv University]]. In August 2007, she worked as a reporter for ''Walla!'', an internet news portal then owned by the [[Bezeq]] and Haaretz groups. She was employed there until 10 March 2010, when she announced a [[leave of absence]]. {{Clear}} === Uri Blau === {{Main article|Uri Blau}} {{Expand section|date=June 2010}} Uri Blau ({{lang-he|אורי בלאו}}, born 1977) is an Israeli writer and journalist and currently an investigative reporter for the ''Haaretz'' newspaper, specializing in military affairs. == Details of the leak == In 2008, Blau published a report{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/idf-ignoring-high-court-on-west-bank-assassinations-1.258296 |title=IDF Ignoring High Court on West Bank Assassinations |last=Blau |first=Uri |authorlink=Uri Blau |date=26 November 2008 |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |accessdate=9 July 2013}} based on these documents, which said that the IDF senior command planned and executed [[targeted killings]] of three people, in violation of an earlier 2006 ruling of the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Israeli Supreme Court]] limiting the circumstances in which such a tactic could be used.
"This is an arrest operation," the document said, attributing the quote to Naveh. "But in case [the soldiers] identify one of the senior leaders of the Islamic Jihad, Walid Obeid, Ziad Malaisha, Adham Yunis, they have permission to open fire in accordance with their appraisal of the situation during the operation."{{cite news |last=Izenberg |first=Dan |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=172983 |title=Stamp of approval from attorney-general |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=13 April 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010}}
The [[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|Chief of General Staff]], Lieutenant General [[Gabi Ashkenazi]] was angered by the leak of highly classified documents, and ordered an investigation about its source. Following a petition for investigation by two Israeli leading human rights attorneys, the Attorney-General [[Menahem Mazuz]] responded in a letter challenging the allegations made by Blau: ::Regarding the killing of Malaisha, Mazuz wrote, "The IDF operation met all the conditions laid down in the [Supreme Court targeted killing ruling]. The attack took place after the possibility of arresting the fugitives was ruled out as being impossible to achieve under the circumstances and after it was made clear to the soldiers that arrest was the first preference." ::Mazuz added "the legal aspects of the operation were examined at each one of the planning stages and there is no basis to the charge that the IDF 'ignored' the High Court's instructions.... On the contrary, the operational officers in the general staff, who had close legal consultation, were aware of the High Court instructions and stressed and carried them out in all stages of the planning and the approval of the operation." According to documents released by The [[Tel Aviv]] [[District Court]], Kamm said during her interrogation: "There were some aspects of the IDF's operational procedures in the West Bank that I felt should be public knowledge... When I was burning the CDs I kept thinking that history tends to forgive people who expose [[war crimes]]".{{cite news|author=Vered Luvitch |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3874912,00.html |title=Kam: History forgives those who expose war crimes |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=12 April 2010 |accessdate=26 October 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002085040/http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0%2C7340%2CL-3874912%2C00.html |archivedate=2 October 2010 |deadurl=no }} The Israeli police secured a gag order prohibiting Israeli media from reporting on Kamm's arrest, and the reasons for it. The charges against Kamm do not relate to her journalistic activities as a media correspondent, but rather to being a journalistic source.{{cite news|title=Middle East Informer|url=http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/Middle-East-Informer-2/600760968595cdc6faa655be6535cb81|accessdate=4 July 2017|agency=Associated Press|date=8 April 2010}} ==Publication of the affair== Despite the fact that numerous foreign media outlets, as well as local blogs, had reported on the case and her identity, there was a gag order within the mainstream media. No printed newspaper had published her name, though many have published reports criticizing the authorities for imposing the gag and preventing them from telling their readers about the major story. The first overseas reporting on the case came in the [[Tikun Olam (blog)|Tikun Olam blog]], which collaborated with Israeli bloggers and journalists to bring the story into the public consciousness. After pressure from articles in the foreign media and from the Israeli press itself, which resented its muzzling, the gag order was removed on 8 April and an indictment was published accusing Kamm of espionage and damaging the security of the state. She faced a possible penalty of life in prison. Reaction among some in the public has been especially harsh, with some calling her a spy and traitor. Kamm's trial was scheduled to begin in May 2010, unless her attorneys arrived at a plea bargain with the prosecution. Though the prosecution originally sought the gag order, in this case Kamm and her attorneys felt it was in her interest to honor it as well. She has exerted great pressure on her supporters not to publicize her arrest or the charges against her. She asked the [[Hebrew Wikipedia]] to remove the article about her (although a deletion vote was opened before her request was made),1. [[:he:שיחה:ענת קם/ארכיון 1|Discussion in Hebrew about Kamm's request]]; 2. [[:he:ויקיפדיה:רשימת מועמדים למחיקה/:ענת קם|The deletion vote in Hebrew]] – Note that two of the voters cited Kamm's request as a reason to delete the article. raised controversy both within the Hebrew Wikipedia community and among free speech and free press advocates within Israel and abroad. The case raised profound questions about the balance between national security and press scrutiny.See, for example: {{cite news |author=Ilene R. Prusher |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2010/0408/Press-freedom-vs.-state-security-Israel-s-Anat-Kam-faces-jail-for-leaking-army-files |title=Press freedom vs. state security: Israel's Anat Kamm faces jail for leaking army files |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=10 September 2014}} and {{cite news |author=Daniella Peled |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/apr/08/anat-kamm-shin-bet-israel |title=The real moral of the Anat Kamm story |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=8 April 2010 |accessdate=10 September 2014}} Advocates for human rights and democracy both within Israel and outside are closely monitoring the case. The Paris-based [[Reporters Without Borders]] issued a statement saying that "Defence of national security is a legitimate objective but censorship must not be used to prevent the Israel Defense Forces from being held responsible if they broke the law."{{cite web |date=6 April 2010 |url=http://en.rsf.org/israel-israeli-media-forbidden-to-report-06-04-2010,36948 |title=Israeli media forbidden to report case widely covered internationally |publisher=[[Reporters Without Borders]] |accessdate=10 September 2014}} Although a gag order was initially issued in late January 2010 while Kamm was in [[house arrest]], the Israeli journalist Yitzhak Tessler of NRG Ma'ariv was the first to refer to the affair in his column where he called journalists to find ways to make the publish the details surrounding the affair. Beside several Israeli blogs, that soon deleted the information they published about the affair (some deleted the information due to the gag order and some due to a request from Kamm herself) and [[HaAyin HaShevi'it|The Seventh Eye]], an Israeli site that discusses the investigation and criticism of the Israeli media, which dropped hints about the affair,{{cite news |author=Hanoch Marmari |url=http://www.the7eye.org.il/41209 |title=It cannot happen here |publisher=[[HaAyin HaShevi'it|The Seventh Eye]] |date=28 March 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}} no Israeli media outlet published any details about Kamm's arrest. Outside of Israel, the first to published details of affair (in mid-March 2010) was [[Richard Silverstein]], a Jewish-American blogger.{{cite news |author=Judith Miller |authorlink=Judith Miller |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2010/04/03/israels-free-press-crackdown.html |title=Israel's Censorship Scandal |publisher=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=April 3, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}} The first full publication (by an established media source) appeared at the end of March 2010 in the Jewish news agency [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] (JTA) from the United States. In the following days the affair was published in many newspapers{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/07/world/middleeast/07israel.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | title=Debate in Israel on Gag Order in Security Leak Case | date=6 April 2010 |page=A12 |accessdate=10 September 2014}}{{cite news | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article7086417.ece | location=London | work=[[The Times]] | first=James | last=Hider | title=Israel arrests soldier Anat Kam over targeted killings leak | date=3 April 2010}}{{subscription required}} and news agencies. After the details of the affair were published in various media outlets worldwide, the Israeli media began to carefully hint about the affair. The ''Haaretz'' newspaper and [[Channel 10 (Israel)|Channel 10]] filed a petition to the District Court in Tel Aviv against the gag order, which was eventually lifted on 8 April. With the removal of the gag order an extensive discussion was held in the Israeli media about Kamm's actions. The dominant approach in the media was that Kamm's actions risked lives without a real justification{{cite news |author=Haim Misgav |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3873510,00.html |script-title=he:מרגלים תמיד יודעים איך עלינו לנהוג |language=he |trans-title=Spies always know how we should act |publisher=[[Ynet]] |date=9 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-02-05}}{{Dubious|date=February 2011}}. Various parties have supported Kamm's actions, including ''Haaretz''.{{cite news |author=Gideon Levy |authorlink=Gideon Levy |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/news/politics/1.1196707 |script-title=he:פרשת ענת קם | במקום לעסוק בגילויים, רודפים את המגלים |language=he |trans-title=Anat Kam affair | Instead of dealing with disclosures, chasing the discoverers |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=9 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-09-10}} Richard Silverstein classified Kamm on the same level of [[Julian Assange]] and [[Chelsea Manning]], as a world-class whistleblower.{{cite news |author=Richard Silverstein |url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/opinion/opinion-opinion/kamm-agrees-to-plea-bargain-israel%E2%80%99s-assange-gets-nine-year-sentence-07022011/ |title=Kamm Agrees to Plea Bargain, Israel's Assange Gets Nine-Year Sentence |publisher=Eurasia Review |date=2011-02-07 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} == Legal proceedings == On 14 January 2010, Kamm was indicted for [[espionage]].{{cite news |author=Shmulik Grossman |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3873277,00.html |title=Attorney: Kam case threatens democracy |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=April 8, 2010 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} On 6 February 2011, Kamm was convicted in the Tel Aviv District Court after pleading guilty in a [[plea bargain]] to leaking more than 2,000 secret military documents to ''Haaretz''.{{cite news |author=Ofra Edelman |url=http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/spages/1213585.html |script-title=he:הפרקליטות: נבקש מאסר ארוך ומשמעותי לענת קם |language=he |trans-title=Prosecution: we request a long and significant sentence for Anat Kam |date=6 February 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208003433/http://www.haaretz.co.il/hasite/spages/1213585.html |archivedate=8 February 2011}} The plea bargain contained that Kamm would not be charged with damaging national security, which carried a life sentence if convicted. Instead, she was charged with leaking classified materials, which carries a 15-year maximum sentence. The prosecution was expected to ask for a nine-year sentence.{{cite news |author=Naama Cohen-Friedman |title=Anat Kam sentenced to 4.5 years in prison |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=30 October 2011 |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4141015,00.html |accessdate=10 September 2014}} On 30 October 2011, Kamm was sentenced to four and a half years in prison and 18 months probation. The panel of judges ruled that the two years Kamm had spent under house arrest would not be deducted from her sentence. Kamm's defense appealed the sentence to the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Israeli Supreme Court]], claiming that the sentence was too harsh. Kamm also requested that her sentence be deferred until a decision was made on the appeal.{{cite news |author=Naama Cohen Friedman |date=16 November 2011 |title=Anat Kam appeals 4.5-year sentence |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4149183,00.html |accessdate=10 September 2014}} In a hearing before Supreme Court justice Miriam Naor, the prosecution accused Kamm of posing a major threat to the state, and claiming that due to her actions, "we are paying the price to this day." Prosecutors also claimed that it was odd that Kamm complained of being judged prematurely by the press when she had previously argued that the public had a right to the information contained in the documents she leaked. Justice Naor accepted the prosecution's arguments and rejected Kamm's appeal. However, she was given three extra days of freedom so she could undergo a medical examination.{{cite news |author=Aviel Magnezi |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4149795,00.html |title=Court rules: Anat Kam to be jailed Wednesday |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=17 November 2011 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} On 23 November, Kamm arrived at [[Neve Tirtza Women's Prison]] in [[Ramla]] to begin serving her sentence.{{cite news |date=23 November 2011 |title=Anat Kam begins serving prison sentence |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4151980,00.html |accessdate=10 September 2014}} Kamm appealed her sentence to the [[Supreme Court of Israel|Israeli Supreme Court]]. On 31 December 2012 the Supreme Court granted her appeal and shortened her sentence to three and a half years by majority decision, noting that she had confessed to the crime, cooperated with the investigation, spent a considerable period of time under house arrest, and is unlikely to make repeat violations. Justices [[Hanan Melcer]] and [[Edna Arbel]] voted in favor of reducing her penalty, while [[Noam Sohlberg]] voted against.{{cite news |author=Aviel Magnezi |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4326565,00.html |title=Court cuts Anat Kam's prison sentence |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=31 December 2012 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} In September 2012, Uri Blau was sentenced to four months of community service for his role in the leak.{{cite news|url=http://www.thehimalayantimes.com/fullNews.php?headline=Israel+reporter+sentenced+over+secret+army+papers&NewsID=345978|title=Israel reporter sentenced over secret army papers|date=4 September 2012|publisher=The Himalayan|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|accessdate=10 September 2014}} In February 2013, Anat Kamm demanded NIS 2 million in compensation from ''Haaretz''. In a letter from her attorney, Ilan Bombach, it was claimed that the newspaper's actions in exposing her as the source of the leaks caused her "great harm" by destroying her budding journalism career and academic studies, and threatened to sue for compensation in court unless the newspaper paid.{{cite news |last=Tucker |first=Nati |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/anat-kamm-demands-nis-2-million-from-haaretz-for-exposing-her.premium-1.501251 |title=Anat Kamm demands NIS 2 million from Haaretz for exposing her - National Israel News |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-05}} Kamm was released after 26 months in January 2014.{{cite news |author=Yaniv Kubovich |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/1.570553 |title=Anat Kamm released after two years in jail |newspaper=[[Haaretz]] |date=26 January 2014 |accessdate=4 May 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Anat Kamm}} * {{cite news |author=Richard Silverstein |url=http://www.richardsilverstein.com/tikun_olam/2010/03/18/shin-bet-detains-israeli-reporter-for-leaking-top-secret-memos-on-targeted-assassinations/ |title=Shin Bet Secretly Detains Reporter for Leaking Top-Secret IDF Memos |publisher=Tikun Olam |date=18 March 2010}} * Mya Guarnieri (Tel Aviv), [http://www.thenational.ae/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/201004\03/FOREIGN/704029822/1002 Israeli journalist to go on trial for treason over leaked papers], ''[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]'', 3 April 2010{{dead link|date=September 2014}} * {{cite web |author=Benjamin Barthe |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/proche-orient/article/2010/04/03/l-histoire-que-la-presse-israelienne-ne-peut-pas-encore-raconter_1328302_3218.html |title=L'histoire que la presse israélienne ne peut pas (encore) raconter |language=fr |trans-title=The story that the Israeli press cannot (yet) tell |newspaper=[[Le Monde]] |date=3 April 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kamm, Anat}} [[Category:Israeli whistleblowers]] [[Category:Israeli journalists]] [[Category:Extrajudicial killings]] [[Category:Political scandals]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Laws of war]] [[Category:2010 in Israel]] [[Category:Classified documents]] [[Category:Espionage scandals and incidents]] [[Category:Women whistleblowers]]

'''Armistice of Malmö''' was a treaty signed on August 26, 1848 following the [[First Schleswig War]] between [[Denmark]] and [[Prussia]]. This treaty forced Prussia and the [[Frankfurt National Assembly]] to accept Danish demands of its annexation of the [[Duchy of Schleswig]] and temporarily maintained the balance between under the pressure from [[United Kingdom|Britain]], [[France]] and [[Russia]]. {{Infobox building |name = ArthaLand Century Pacific Tower |image = |location = [[Bonifacio Global City]], [[Taguig City]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]] |coordinates = |status = Under Construction |start_date = |completion_date = |est_completion = 2017 |opening = |building_type = Office |antenna_spire = |roof = {{convert|136|m|ft|abbr=on}} |top_floor = |floor_count = 32 |cost = ₱3.5 billion |floor_area = {{convert|62000|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} | grounds_area = {{convert|2232|m2|sqft|abbr=on}} | architecture_firm = [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] |architect = |structural_engineer= |main_contractor = |developer = ArthaLand |owner = |management = |references = <ref>{{cite web|title=ArthaLand Century Pacific Tower|url=http://www.som.com/projects/arthaland_century_pacific_tower|publisher=Skidmore, Owings & Merrill|accessdate=1 December 2016}}</ref> }} The '''ArthaLand Century Pacific Tower''' is a 32-storey office building under construction in [[Bonifacio Global City]] in [[Taguig]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]].<ref name=kmc>{{cite web|title=ArthaLand Tower to Rise across the Shangri-La Hotel and the PSE|url=http://kmcmaggroup.com/blog/2014/7/23/arthaland-tower-to-rise-across-the-shangri-la-hotel-and-the-pse/|website=KMCA Group|publisher=Yves Luethi|accessdate=8 January 2016|archive-date=28 July 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728132507/http://kmcmaggroup.com/blog/2014/7/23/arthaland-tower-to-rise-across-the-shangri-la-hotel-and-the-pse/}}</ref> The construction cost of the building owned by Arthaland Corporation is around {{Philippine peso|3.5 billion}} and is slated to be completed by 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dumlao|first1=Doris|title=P3.5-B Arthaland Tower rising in BGC|url=http://business.inquirer.net/173695/p3-5-b-arthaland-tower-rising-in-bgc|accessdate=24 July 2014|publisher=Inquirer|date=27 June 2014}}</ref>
==Design and Features== The ArthaLand Tower will have 21 office floors, 14 elevators, and high-end retail outlets and other retail establishments at the ground floor and podium. It is [[Philippine Economic Zone Authority]] accredited and is aiming for LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environment Design Program) Gold and BERDE (Building for Ecologically Responsive Design Excellence) certification.<ref name=kmc/>
The office building was designed by [[Skidmore, Owings & Merrill]] (SOM) of New York, architect of [[One World Trade Center]] in [[New York City]]. This building is designed in collaboration with Filipino architectural firm, GF & Partners Architects Co.<ref>{{cite web|title=ArthaLand to build P3.5-B office tower in Global City|url=http://www.tribune.net.ph/business/arthaland-to-build-p3-5-b-office-tower-in-global-city|website=tribune.net.ph|publisher=tribune|accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref>
It building will have 28,000 sqm. of net leasable area out of a gross floor area of 34,000sqm.<ref name=kmc/>
==Reception== The building received the Best Green Development and Highly Commended in the Best Office Architectural Design at the Philippines Property Awards 2016. At the South East Asia Property Awards 2016, the ArthaLand Tower was conferred with the Special Recognition in Sustainable Design.<ref>{{cite news|title=ArthaLand Century Pacific Tower wins international awards|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/network/business/2016/11/28/arthaland-century-pacific-tower-wins-international-awards-512048|accessdate=1 December 2016|work=Sun Star|date=28 November 2016}}</ref>
